Irish Rover perfect winter spot

Irish Rover perfect winter spot

Nancy Miller, Special to The Courier-Journal 12:55 p.m. EST November 19, 2014

The Irish Rover is at 2319 Frankfort Ave.(Photo: Jessica Ebelhar/The Courier-Journal)

Story Highlights

  • 3 1/2 stars out of 4
  • Address: 2319 Frankfort Ave. Telephone: (502) 899-3544 Web: theirishroverky.com
  • Cuisine: Irish. Alcohol: Full bar.Vegetarian: Yes. Price range: Inexpensive to moderate.
  • Hours: Monday-Thursday, 11:30 a.m.-10 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, 11:30 a.m.-11 p.m.
CONNECT 11 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

I'm a gung-ho advocate of the farm-to-table movement and wholeheartedly support chefs eschewing traditional boundaries and pushing innovation. But sometimes it's nice to go out to dinner and not read on the menu or be told the details of where the cow you're about to eat grazed before it met its demise or where the pea pods sprouted before they were artfully arranged on your plate.

One snappily cool evening last week, neither my mind nor palate was in the mood for fusion or boundary pushing or surprise bursts of flavors. And, quite frankly, my son Alex and I were up for a meal that didn't regale us with its Kentucky roots or the attributes of the commonwealth's soil.

We were ready for the Irish Rover. The Rover, as it's called by devotees, was ready for us. That's being a tad self-aggrandizing because the restaurant is perpetually ready for anyone. Walk in and you feel at home. Sit down and you won't want to leave. We stayed longer than necessary thanks to a dessert of bread and butter pudding ($4.95). But who are we kidding? We stayed because it was warm (literally and figuratively) and amicably pubby.

The two front dining rooms are pleasant enough. But the real atmosphere is in the bar where dark green and brick walls, booths, a weathered bar and a series of coats-of-arms coax your imagination into believing you're in a pub on the Emerald Isle. While they do a bang-up job of coaxing, there's always the option of a pint of Guinness or a dram of Scotch to hasten the process.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Olive Leaf Bistro in Jeff

All the staff may not speak with a brogue, but owners Michael and Siobhan Reidy must vet their prospective staff for easy-going friendliness. It works like an Irish charm. I have been to The Irish Rover many times and have never received anything but excellent service. Then again, service is too formal a word. Being served there is more akin to having a friend bring you something straight from his kitchen.

If you take kids to The Irish Rover, how can they not order Bubble & Squeak (fried mashed potatoes, veggies and onions, $2.95) if for no reason other than their asking for it by its whimsical name? Purportedly, it makes bubble and squeaking sounds as it cooks. I wouldn't know since I have never fixed it at home, but I like to think it's true.

A Scotch egg ($3.95) is a hard-boiled egg wrapped in sausage. Somehow the sausage doesn't crumble or detach from the egg during deep-frying. Chef Terrence Burbridge has probably made thousands of them and has perfected a wonder of a sausage and egg combo.

DISH | Dundee Tavern to re-open as gastropub

READ MORE | Four Roses upgrades second Bourbon Trail stop

It wasn't long ago (maybe only last week?) that I complained that a restaurant's menu was overloaded with mashed potatoes. You'll hear no complaints from me about mashed potatoes featuring prominently in several Irish Rover dishes. The potatoes are a delicious part and parcel of many traditional Irish dishes, such as Bangers & Mash. Two plump Irish sausages perch on top of a mound of the potatoes. Priced at $6.95, it's a steal of a rich dish.

Bread and Butter pudding at The Irish Rover restaurant, which is located on Frankfort Avenue. Nov. 13, 2014. (Photo: , Jessica Ebelhar/The Courier-Journal)

    Last SlideNext Slide

    I suppose it's true that you can't miss what you've never had, but if you've never had Burbridge's stuffed cabbage ($12.95) you're missing a high-powered, flavorful dish that's about as close to gourmet comfort food as you can come. A full-toned red wine reduction enhances the ground lamb and smoked cheddar inside the cabbage.

    Wherever the idea of meat and potatoes got a low-brow reputation, it wasn't at The Rover. The cottage pie ($10.95) reprises the mashed potatoes by topping them over the heartiest of hearty beef stews served in a bread bowl. I've eaten it in the middle of the summer and never once thought of it as strictly a winter dish. But now that winter is coming at us more quickly than we anticipated, it's prime time for the cottage pie.

    The Irish Rover is one of Louisville's best spots for mixing and mingling with the regulars who will very quickly make you feel like one of the home crowd. They, and the staff, will be more than happy to help you wind your way through the wine list and top-notch selection of beers, wines, whiskeys, Scotches and cocktails.

    You can email freelance restaurant critic Nancy Miller at millermadison@aol.com. Follow @WhatNancyThinks on Twitter.
